feedback.Physical object: Excluded — A law is an abstract construct with no inherent materiality.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Excluded — This trait is reserved for tangible, constructed entities.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — Laws evolve over time through amendments.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — The structure is conceptual, not physical.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — Perception occurs through its representations.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — The document is material, but the law is not.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — Not relevant for non-material entities.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Excluded — While created intentionally, the law itself is not a functioning agent.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — Enforcement causes effects, not the law intrinsically.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — Law is referenced and interpreted, not autonomously processing anything.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — It does not possess a mutable state.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — It is intermediated through institutions or documents.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Fundamental to society, but not to a system in a functional engineering sense.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Expresses abstract rights, duties, and principles.
feedback.Communicative: Included — Written and broadcast to inform behavior and expectations.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Defines structured conditions for permission, prohibition, and enforcement.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Included — Legal systems organize laws into articles, sections, and precedence structures.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Explicitly intended to guide and constrain human action.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — A law does not inherently refer to itself.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — While it has temporal conditions (e.g. durations), that is not intrinsic to all laws.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Applicability depends on jurisdiction, context, and interpretation.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Law is an institutional norm system.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Formally defined by governments or courts.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Included — It governs authorship, ownership, and access.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Included — It is the codification of governance.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — A foundation of civic and legal education.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Application and enforcement vary by case and region.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Copyright is a well-known concept even among laypeople.

encoding_notes: This encoding captures Copyright Law as an abstract, symbolic, behavior-guiding system embedded in formal social regulation. It deliberately excludes all physical and functional traits, emphasizing law’s identity as a logical rule set that exists only through social consensus and institutional enforcement. The prior omission of hierarchical structure has been corrected to reflect legal modularity.
